Gordon,

I was able to add some logging and can reproduce a SEVERE error that 
will cause the thread to crash reliably.  I am hoping that you can help 
me put a fix in for this problem.


--David

In BdbMultiWorkQueues.java

I added at line 271 (right before retVal = 
(CrawlURI)crawlUriBinding.entryToObject(result);):

             LOGGER.log(Level.INFO, "DAP "
                     + " getNextNearestItem was SUCCESS: "
                     + status
                     + ", headKey "
                     + BdbWorkQueue.getPrefixClassKey(headKey.getData()) 

                     + ", result "
                     + result);

On 1/8/2012 2:58 PM, Gordon Mohr wrote:
> On 1/6/12 8:38 AM, David Pane wrote:
>> Gordon,
>>
>> I ran into this problem a month or so ago and spent a few days trying to
>> track down why this was happening. I could not reliably find a way to
>> reproduce the problem. It took close to 1 hr to recover (It took about
>> the same amount of time for each of the 5 instances) from the last
>> checkpoint. So, repeatedly resuming from the checkpoint to reproduce the
>> same errors will be very time consuming.
>>
>> You have stated a number of times in the past that SEVERE errors need to
>> be resolved. This certainly concerns me especially if we cannot recover
>> from checkpoints if we need to. As far as I can tell, the other threads
>> are making progress. Is there something that I should be checking to
>> verify this? The other side effects of the SEVERE errors concern me, but
>> not as much as not being able to recover. What does IA do when they are
>> in a middle of an important data collection crawl and they run into
>> something like this? Our crawl is time critical so I hate to stop
>> crawling.
>
> If the crawl.log is still growing with new entries, and any WARCs are
> still be written... there's progress. But as I'd mentioned, the death of
> the threads means that the URI it was trying to read, and probably the
> entire host-based-queue that contained, is no longer in the normal
> rotation. So for example, in the instance you say shows 1172 threads, I
> suspect that 28 queues (hostnames) of URIs are no longer being consulted
> for URIs to crawl.
>
> I don't know if future checkpoints after this point will succeed, or
> would be resumable even if they appeared to succeed; there's not enough
> info about what went wrong. Presumably whatever caused the topmost-URI
> deserialization to fail will remain as a problem unless the code or
> data-on-disk changes, so those queues might continue to be inert even
> with some heroic tampering with heap state or the on-disk data.
>
> What would happen on an IA crawl would depend on the tradeoffs involved,
> but if there are errors suggesting data loss or skipping of intended
> collection content, usually those problems are investigated to
> resolution, occasional with catch-up or 'patch' crawling a bit later to
> fill known gaps.
>
>> The instance that had the previous problem was instance #0. This
>> instance was just subjected to the same thread crash problem about 3
>> hours ago. (it is now running on 1199 threads). Since the restart of
>> this thread, besides for the above mentioned SEVERE error, it received
>> 12 SEVERE errors immediately following the resume. These 12 were are
>> similar to:
>> Failed store of DNS Record for dns:www.francfranc.com (in thread
>> 'ToeThread #352: dns:www.francfranc.com'; in processor 'fetchDns')
>> 2012
>
> These are also a concern, but perhaps just local to the record that
> could not be stored, and probably unrelated to the thread-death errors.
> The full stacks & other configuration info would be helpful, as well as
> knowing whether such errors only happened after, or also before, the
> checkpoint-resume.
>
>> The only modification that I made was in SurtPrefixedDecideRule. I
>> modified it to evaluate the ip addresses in my blacklist along with the
>> SURT values.
>>
>> Looking back in the heritix_out.log for instance #4, I found a number of
>> SEVERE problems (107 including the 37 that occurred since the restart).
>> Although there are SEVERE errors reporting problems creating checkpoints
>> certain checkpoints, I recovered from cp00282 (a checkpoint that did not
>> have a problem being created.
>>
>> There has not been a severe error for over 12 hrs on this instance. The
>> crawler instance in using 1172 of 1172 so I lost 28 threads due to the
>> errors causing the threads to crash.
>>
>> I also have seen over 200 warnings. 111 are similar to this:
>
> None of the WARNINGs are likely related to the thread-death issue,
> though the about 'politessDelay unset' [sic] is a bit perplexing for
> other reasons, and the one at "2011-12-28 18:02:57.554" about a "Problem
> line" suggests to me you might be feeding URIs into the crawler in a way
> that doesn't match your intent (if an "F+" line of that format was being
> considered at that time).
>
>> Maybe this isn't helpful, below is the output I got when I did a grep
>> for SEVERE in the heritrix_out.log. It cuts off the details of the
>> severe errors, but you can see there are many issues that could be
>> causing the problem.
>
> Indeed there are a bunch of things there that warrant some investigation.
>
> The 'NegativeArraySizeException' errors look like they should be caught
> differently, and logged as WARNINGs rather than SEVERE, but probably
> only affect those exact URIs.
>
> The "unable to create required checkpoint link" errors are a concern, as
> they appear to happen intermittently both before and after your resume.
> Any checkpoint that encounters such an error will definitely be
> incomplete/damaged in its checkpoint directory files. If the hardlinking
> we're doing has momentary transient failures, perhaps the Heritrix code
> should be retrying a few times.
>
> To refresh my memory and for reference, what is your OS/JVM?
>
> Even after looking through this added inf, I don't have any clear idea
> why the "SerializationException: Buffer limit exceeded" errors are
> occurring. Getting to the bottom of that will probably require being
> able to retrigger the error and collect more data about the
> circumstances just before/during that failure.
>
> - Gordon
>
>> Kind regards,
>>
>> David

>> On 1/6/2012 4:12 AM, Gordon Mohr wrote:
>>> SEVERE errors always mean something that is likely
>>> crawl-fouling/corrupting has occurred.
>>>
>>> In this case, it appears the SEVERE errors killed the threads in which
>>> they occurred while reading the top URI from their respective queues. At
>>> the very least the URI in process will not be crawled; it is also likely
>>> the entire queue it came from is no longer in frontier rotation, and the
>>> crawl may not checkpoint/terminate clearly. (That's even if other
>>> threads still appear to be making progress... are they?)
>>>
>>> If these errors all happened only *after* checkpoint-resumption, it
>>> might be possible to find the cause or a workaround, and then again
>>> resume (more successfully without errors). However, it's also possible
>>> that these are reflecting earlier latent corruption in the
>>> earlier-crawl/checkpointed data.
>>>
>>> Are any of the instances showing the problem (2,4) the one that had the
>>> other hung-checkpoint problem? (Do you have any idea what had triggered
>>> the IO-exceptions that were correlated with those failed/hung
>>> checkpoints?)
>>>
>>> Did the SEVERE SerializationExceptions occur right after resumption, or
>>> did they happen over a longer period (perhaps with more occcurences
>>> since the initial report)?
>>>
>>> If for one of the affected instances, you try another resume from the
>>> exact same checkpoint, do the exact same number of errors occur?
>>>
>>> I vaguely recall seeing a similar error when first converting to the
>>> 'Kryo' serialization (for compactness and speed), but believe the error
>>> at that time was quickly fixed (and no JIRA issue mentions the same
>>> BufferUnderflowException root cause). Our 'KryoBinding' class creates an
>>> ObjectBuffer that's supposed to grow as large as necessary (max-size:
>>> Integer.MAX_VALUE), so it should never be too small (but might trigger
>>> another kind of failure if it were growing without practical limit).
>>>
>>> Do the affected instances (2,4) show any other alert/WARNING/SEVERE log
>>> output, before or after the checkpoint-resume cycle?
>>>
>>> Have you made any customizations to CrawlURI or added/modified objects
>>> that might be stored inside a CrawlURI?
>>>
>>> I don't really know what's happening, but if you have a well-preserved
>>> checkpoint which can be repeatedly resumed to reproduce the exact same
>>> flurry of errors, there's a chance more testing (including added logging
>>> code) can be done to figure out exactly what's going wrong. Whether it's
>>> fixable in your checkpoints, or only for future crawls, remains to be
>>> seen.
>>>
>>> - Gordon
>>>
